title: U.S. aluminum prices hit record highs amid tariffs, low supply
summary: U.S. aluminum prices have surged 40% since tariffs were raised to 50%, with the Midwest premium hitting a record high due to tight global supplies and low inventories. President Trump's doubled tariffs aim to boost local production, but consumers face costs above $5,200 per metric ton. Exporters have diverted aluminum to Europe, exacerbating U.S. shortages.

title: US aluminium prices break away as tariffs collide with global supply strain
summary: US aluminum prices exceed USD 5,000 per tonne as tariffs up to 50%, falling imports, and shrinking stocks collide with Europe's supply shocks from sanctions and CBAM. Premiums are 68% over LME prices, straining industries like automotive and construction. China's production growth has slowed, nearing a 45 million tonne cap.

title: US ALUMINUM: Historically wide spreads in prime scrap market change 2026 contract behavior
summary: Wide spreads in US aluminum scrap markets, driven by record Midwest premiums, tariff uncertainty, and supply-demand shifts, are disrupting 2026 contracts. UBC scrap prices averaged 111.25 cents/lb in January, at 46% of MWT costs, down from prior norms. Buyers and sellers hesitate on long-term deals amid policy volatility and scrap gluts.

title: What Contractors Need to Know About Metal Prices Right Now
summary: This metal roofing update highlights tight US aluminum supply pushing prices to four-year highs, driven by ingot values and premiums. Energy costs, winter weather, and lean inventories across the supply chain are extending lead times. Contractors are advised to manage risks for Q1-Q2 projects amid volatility.

title: The Proportion of Liquid Aluminum in January Declined, Expected to Face a Significant Drop in February - SMM Analysis
summary: China's aluminum production in January 2026 increased 2.7% YoY and 0.5% MoM, but the proportion of liquid aluminum declined 4.4 percentage points to 72.1% due to weak demand, high prices, and production restrictions. As of end-January, existing aluminum capacity stood at 46.209 million mt and operating capacity at 44.996 million mt. February production is forecast to drop MoM with fewer days, and liquid aluminum proportion expected to fall sharply to 64.4% amid Chinese New Year and weak downstream demand.

title: Alcoa expects higher alumina & aluminum output for 2026
summary: Alcoa forecasts alumina production of 9.7 to 9.9 million tons and aluminum output of 2.4 to 2.6 million tons for 2026. This increase is attributed to smelter expansions and improved operations.

title: US aluminium prices break away as tariffs collide with global supply strain
summary: US aluminum prices have surged past USD 5000 per tonne due to tariffs boosting domestic production like Century Aluminum's Mt. Holly restart (50,000 tonnes capacity), falling imports, low stocks, and European supply disruptions from smelter issues and sanctions. China's production growth slowed to 2% in 2025 under a 45 million tonne cap. New US projects face power supply challenges.

title: Aluminum and copper prices take breather after explosive start to 2026
summary: Aluminum prices steadied at $3,197.50 a ton on the LME, the highest in over three years, following a strong start to 2026 amid bullish industrial metals run. Concerns include potential softening Chinese demand and geopolitical risks from US tariffs on countries trading with Iran.

title: Surface Treatment Breakthroughs for Recycled, New Aluminum Alloys
summary: Innovations in surface treatments like anodizing for recycled and new aluminum alloys are enhancing durability and sustainability in automotive and construction applications. Recycled aluminum reduces energy consumption by up to 95%, supporting eco-friendly goals. These advances improve material performance amid rising demand in electric vehicles and energy-efficient buildings.

title: Uzbekistan Launches Its First Aluminum Can Plant with IFC Support to Drive Sustainable Production
summary: IFC is investing in East Can Solutions to build Uzbekistan's first aluminum can plant in Tashkent, producing up to 1.1 billion recyclable cans annually using energy-efficient equipment. The facility will create over 200 jobs, reduce emissions, and strengthen local supply chains while aligning with international sustainability standards. This supports Uzbekistan's climate goals and promotes greener packaging for beverages.

title: ASI Newsletter – January 2026
summary: The ASI Newsletter highlights the 2026 standards revision process, World Bank insights on standards, and efforts in benchmarking for sustainability in the aluminum value chain. It covers initiatives like co-creating data ecosystems for circular economy and mapping Colombia’s aluminum recycling chain. These updates emphasize GHG emissions reduction and inclusive participation toward 2030 priorities.

title: Smart Coding & Aluminium for Circular Packaging
summary: Aluminum cans are leading sustainability in circular packaging, with innovations in high-speed, low-waste coding for beverage brands. The article discusses how advanced coding enables efficiency and reduces environmental impact. It ties into broader trends like GS1 2D codes for breaking speed barriers in sustainable manufacturing.

title: Steel Prices Rising Again? February 2026 Metal Market Update
summary: Steel prices continue to rise with extended lead times from mills, while aluminum supply remains tight at four-year price highs. Energy costs and winter weather are impacting production, keeping inventory levels lean across the supply chain. Contractors are advised to manage risk and protect margins for Q1 and Q2 projects amid pricing volatility.

title: Feb 2026 Metals Market: Pricing, Supply & Buyer Insights
summary: Carbon and alloy steel markets remain balanced with spot pricing stable within ±2–4%, while several metals have seen 3–8% price increases since Q4 2025 due to energy costs and supply factors. Aluminium pricing is up 4–6% year-to-date amid capacity constraints, and stainless steel alloy surcharges remain elevated. Buyers should evaluate Q2–Q3 needs to manage volatility.

title: Steelmaking raw material prices increase through January
summary: All but one steelmaking raw material tracked increased in price over the last month, with collective prices up 8% month-over-month. Coking coal hit a 1.5-year high of $249/dmt, up 14% m/m, while pig iron rose 5% to $430/dmt. Iron ore declined slightly to $106/dmt but remains above $100/dmt for six months.

title: Adjustment Information on the Product Price Policies of Ansteel and Bensteel Group for February 2026
summary: Angang Steel adjusted its product price policy for February 2026 based on January levels. The changes reflect ongoing market adjustments for hot-rolled and other products. This follows trends in futures and spot markets amid steel industry dynamics.

title: US raw steel production is up 1.3 percent - week 4, 2026
summary: According to the American Iron and Steel Institute (AISI), US domestic raw steel production for the week ending January 24, 2026, was 1.778 million net tons with a capacity utilization rate of 76.9 percent. This represents a 1.3 percent increase from the previous week and a 4.6 percent increase compared to the same week in 2025. Year-to-date adjusted production through January 24, 2026, reached 6.016 million net tons at 75.9 percent capacity utilization, up 3.4 percent from the prior year.

title: Steel Prices Rising Again? February 2026 Metal Market Update
summary: This market update discusses rising steel mill prices and extended lead times in the metal roofing industry, alongside tight aluminum supply reaching four-year price highs. The analysis covers how energy costs and winter weather are impacting production, why inventory levels remain lean across the supply chain, and recommendations for contractors managing Q1 and Q2 projects.

title: Feb 2026 Metals Market: Pricing, Supply & Buyer Insights
summary: Carbon and alloy steel markets remain balanced entering Q1 with spot pricing relatively stable at ±2–4% movement. The report notes that metals have experienced 3–8% price movement compared to Q4 2025 levels, driven by energy costs and alloy inputs, while stainless steel production remains disciplined and titanium lead times extend 20–30+ weeks.

title: Trump Says U.S. Produces More Steel Than Japan for First Time in 26 Years
summary: President Trump highlighted that the U.S. is now producing more steel than Japan for the first time in 26 years, marking a historic comeback in U.S. manufacturing. He noted that steel companies were closing four years ago but have since recovered, with multiple steel plants currently being built.

title: US Overtakes Japan In Steel Production For First Time In 26 Years
summary: The U.S. outpaced Japan in crude steel production for the first time in 26 years in 2025, becoming the world's third-largest steel producer behind China and India.

title: Green Steel Production: Hydrogen Tech & Future Trends
summary: Green steel production is revolutionizing manufacturing through hydrogen-based technology and clean energy solutions. This innovation focuses on decarbonisation and its impact in 2026. It highlights sustainable methods to reduce emissions in steelmaking.

title: Future of Steel: Trends, Technology & Sustainability 2026
summary: The article examines upcoming trends in steel, including sustainability, scrap recycling, and new low-carbon technologies. These innovations are set to reshape steel production by 2026. Emphasis is placed on advancing sustainable practices in the industry.

title: Steel Times International Issue January/February 2026
summary: This issue covers driving a sustainable future in steel, with sections on decarbonisation and GHG emissions tracking. It discusses the year ahead, energy trends, and digital solutions for the industry. Topics include digitalisation to enhance sustainability.

title: CME Hikes Copper Margins Amid Record Price Surge
summary: Global copper prices have reached unprecedented levels, prompting CME Group to raise margins on copper futures by 20% effective January 30, 2026, due to extreme volatility. Prices on the LME exceeded $6 per pound, or over $14,000 per metric tonne. Analysts like Goldman Sachs forecast a decline to $11,000-$11,500 per tonne by year-end 2026 amid potential U.S. tariffs.

title: Copper prices hit yet another record on supply and tariff fears
summary: Copper prices surged to a record $13,225 per tonne on the LME, up 1.8%, driven by supply disruptions like strikes in Chile and delays in Ecuador, plus U.S. tariff concerns. The metal has gained 6.6% in 2026 after a 42% rise in 2025, fueled by AI demand and energy transition expectations. Traders question if speculative inflows exceed fundamentals.

title: Can Copper Extend Its Gains in 2026? | Presented by CME Group
summary: Copper rallied above $6.00 per pound in early 2026 after 40% gains in 2025, with surging demand projected to reach 42 million metric tons by 2040 due to AI data centers. Key factors include U.S. premiums at record levels, Fed policy, and China stimulus, amid high volatility over 31%. Consensus targets range from $5 to $6.35 per pound.

title: Codelco expects to lift copper output by 10,000t this year
summary: Chilean state-run miner Codelco plans to produce 1.344 million metric tons of copper in 2026, an increase of about 10,000 tons from 1.33 million tons in 2025. Chairman Maximo Pacheco highlighted investments in exploration and structural projects to expand mine life amid declining ore grades and operational challenges at mines like El Teniente. The company also aims to boost lithium production through its joint venture with SQM.

title: INTERVIEW: Viscaria to ramp up Sweden's mined copper output by a third
summary: The Viscaria copper mine in Kiruna, Sweden, is set to reopen by 2028, processing 3 million metric tons of ore annually to produce 26,000-30,000 metric tons of copper in concentrate, representing 3% of Europe's primary copper production. The project includes an underground mine and processing plant, with potential for expansion due to ongoing discoveries, and will also yield iron ore byproduct. Operations emphasize a low CO2 footprint amid resilient copper demand.

title: Can copper hit $15000 in 2026?
summary: Codelco's copper production reached 1.332 million tons in 2025 with plans for a modest increase in 2026, but faces declining ore grades and higher costs. Supply disruptions include 500,000 tons lost from a Freeport-McMoRan mine accident and delays at Kamoa-Kakula pushing its 500,000-ton target to 2027, with 6.4 million tons of global capacity stalled due to ESG issues. Projects like Troilus advance toward production with secured financing and permits expected in H2 2026.

title: Copper for Tomorrow: Sustainable copper production
summary: The Copper for Tomorrow bid seeks to address challenges in the copper value chain to boost sustainable production amid rising demand for clean energy transition. It tackles the paradox of increasing output from lower-grade ores using less energy, water, and waste, while electrifying mining operations. The initiative unites industry and researchers to meet ESG goals and double global production sustainably over the next 30 years.

title: Ten major mining tech trends in 2026: Part 1
summary: The article highlights key mining technology trends for 2026, including innovations to recover 40 billion pounds of copper from waste stockpiles, as noted by Freeport's chief sustainability officer. It emphasizes that companies pioneering these technologies will lead the future mining sector. Focus is on sustainable advancements in copper and broader mining operations.

title: Rio Tinto and Groupe CH launch technology that can produce copper in a more sustainable way
summary: Rio Tinto and Groupe CH have launched a new technology aimed at producing copper more sustainably. This innovation supports efforts to meet growing demand while improving environmental performance in copper production.

title: Nickel - Price - Chart - Historical Data - News
summary: Nickel rose to 17,395 USD/T on February 3, 2026, up 2.05% from the previous day. Over the past month, prices have risen 0.58%, and are up 13.36% compared to the same time last year. On February 2, nickel hit a 4-week low of 16,867 USD/T before rebounding.

title: Nickel Prices Plunge as Macro Fund Outflows and High Inventories Weigh on Market
summary: On February 2, 2026, nickel prices experienced limit-down declines due to macro fund outflows and high inventories, with LME stocks over 280,000 mt and domestic visible inventory elevated. China's refined nickel production rose 20% month-on-month in January, increasing supply pressure amid weak downstream demand. Short-term pressure persists, but Indonesian quota reductions could support a rebound.

title: Nornickel sees 2026 nickel output broadly in line with previous year
summary: Nornickel produced 198,521 tons of nickel in 2025, a 3% drop from the previous year, and expects 2026 output to remain broadly in line with that level. The decline is attributed to ore reserve depletion and sanctions-related equipment issues, with recovery anticipated by 2028 through projects like the Skalisty mine expansion. The company sees steady demand and no plans for artificial cuts.

title: Nickel Prices Jump After Top Producer Indonesia Signals 2026 Output Cut
summary: Indonesia plans to cut nickel production in 2026 to balance supply and demand, following a sharp rise in LME inventories. Nickel prices jumped to $16,500 per tonne after the announcement, as the country, holding 60.2% of global market share, aims to curb surplus and support prices. This mirrors actions by the DRC in cobalt production.

title: Nickel Higher on Mine Suspension
summary: Nickel prices rose 1.6% to $16,910 following the suspension of Vale's Indonesia mine and government plans to cut nickel ore output by a third in 2026. The Indonesian mining minister announced reduced quotas to support prices amid recent market support.

title: Can nickel prices hit $25000 in 2026?
summary: Indonesia, producing two-thirds of global nickel, has signaled major 2026 supply cuts including slashing quotas, delaying permits, and halting new smelters, triggering price rallies to $16,500–$18,500 per ton. PT Vale Indonesia halted operations in early January due to quota issues, highlighting stricter enforcement. This shift emphasizes non-Indonesian sulphide projects like Canada Nickel's Crawford.

title: Indonesian Mining Restrictions Send Shockwaves Through Global Nickel Market
summary: Nickel prices surged $2,200 per ton to $18,650 in early 2026 after Vale's Indonesian mining permit delays confirmed real supply constraints. Restrictions coincide with weak alternative supplies like from the Philippines, potentially pushing prices to $20,000 in Q1. Canada Nickel expanded resources at its Reid deposit amid growing demand for non-Indonesian supply.

title: Nickel price extends drop amid lack of detail on Indonesia output cuts
summary: Nickel prices fell 4.1% to $17,155 after Indonesia provided no details on its 2026 production cut pledge, despite earlier surges to $18,800 on supply concerns. The top producer aims to balance supply and demand, but quota figures are still being finalized.

title: Indonesia caps 2026 nickel output while APNI warns of financial pressure on miners
summary: Indonesia's Ministry of Energy and Mineral Resources set the 2026 nickel production quota at 250-260 million tons to align output with demand. The Association of Nickel Producers Indonesia (APNI) warns of potential financial strain on miners from the cap.

title: Indonesia cuts 2026 nickel quota, global prices jump immediately
summary: Indonesia reduced its 2026 nickel quota, sparking immediate global price jumps due to supply concerns.

title: The growing role of critical minerals in global innovation
summary: Leaders at the World Economic Forum Annual Meeting 2026 are exploring how to responsibly mine critical minerals like nickel for green technologies while protecting the environment and driving economic growth. Demand for these minerals, essential for EVs, solar panels, and wind turbines, is projected to rise over 3.4 times by 2040 under net-zero scenarios. The article emphasizes building trust through environmental stewardship, social impact, and alignment with climate goals in mining practices.[1]

title: Will Nickel Replace Lithium? The High-Stakes Race for Next-Gen Battery Dominance
summary: The article discusses the competition between nickel and lithium in next-generation batteries, highlighting sustainability efforts in nickel production. Companies are focusing on eco-friendly mining and recycling through closed-loop systems to support sustainable battery technologies. This innovation aims to address environmental concerns in the race for battery dominance.[7]

title: This USA Nickel Junior Miner Is Getting Attention Early In 2026
summary: Homeland Nickel, a Canadian-based explorer with nickel projects in Oregon, is gaining attention amid a nickel price turnaround since late 2025. CEO Steve Balch discusses 2026 plans, including potential open-pit mining, processing options like shipping to Nevada for battery metal production near Tesla facilities, and traditional smelting for stainless steel or batteries. The video highlights opportunities in U.S. nickel supply for sustainable EV chains.[5]

title: Prysmian signs €2.3 billion contract for UK power link project
summary: Italian cable maker Prysmian has signed a contract worth over €2.3 billion with SP Energy Networks and National Grid to build a power link between Scotland and England. The project, called Eastern Green Link 4, will connect the electrical grids of Scotland and England as part of a significant infrastructure project for the Italian firm.

title: Prysmian to Acquire Submarine Cable Survey and Installation Company ACSM for €169 Million
summary: Prysmian Group announced the acquisition of Spanish specialist ACSM for €169 million (approximately $200 million) on an all-cash basis, with an expected closing by February 2026. The acquisition allows Prysmian to offer end-to-end solutions from cable manufacturing to surveying and installation, internalizing marine services previously subcontracted.
